Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.answerText: A: Acute posterior multifocal placoid pigment epitheliopathy

answers.explanation: Acute macular neuroretinopathy (AMNR) is a rare disease that predominantly affects young women. AMNR is characterized by the sudden onset of paracentral scotomas, most often after a fever or viral infection. OCT findings in AMNR include initial hyper-reflectivity in the outer nuclear layer followed by focal ellipsoid zone disruption.

answers.answerText: D: Multiple evanescent white dot syndrome

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What other investigation may be useful in confirming the diagnosis?

answers.explanation: Patients with AMNR are expected to have normal findings on indocyanine green and fluorescein angiography, whereas infrared fundus photography may reveal oval or wedge-shaped macular lesions that are otherwise not seen on regular fundoscopic exam (1).

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: What is the most likely prognosis for her visual field defect?

answers.answerText: A: Unilateral progression of the defect
B: Progression to involve the other eye
C: Persistence or partial resolution of the defect
answers.explanation: Most patients with AMNR will continue to have a permanent visual field defect, although a small minority will experience partial resolution of their visual field defect (1).

answers.answerText: D: Complete resolution of the defect

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: What is the next best step in management?

answers.answerText: B: Initiate treatment with daily aspirin
D: No further treatment is required
answers.explanation:
There are currently no treatments for the VF defects seen in AMNR. Although there are rare associations of AMNR with certain risk factors such as caffeine consumption and oral contraceptive use, there is no known treatment for the vision loss or preventative measures. In this case, there was a temporal association with COVID-19 and precautions to avoid future infection were recommended. 

Temporal association with COVID-19 has been reported with AMNR. Similar temporal associations have been reported with AMNR and other febrile infections (e.g., influenza, enteritis sinusitis, bronchitis, etc.), oral contraceptive use, epinephrine/ephedrine use, and high-impact trauma (1).

title: Case 24
description: 22F presenting with painless, blurred vision OS for 2 weeks
patientPresentation:
**Contributor:** Arshia Eshtiaghi (CC3)

A 22-year old woman presented to a neuro-ophthalmology clinic with a 2-week history of painless, blurred vision in the left eye. Four weeks prior, she experienced a bout of fever and cough; she tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 infection. On examination, vision was 20/20 OD and 20/25 OS. Pupils were equal and reactive to light with no RAPD. Humphrey 24-2 SITA-Fast visual field testing revealed a paracentral defect OS, as shown below:
